critique: This executive order pertains to the civil service status of employees at the General Accounting Office (GAO). It allows certain employees, appointed before July 1, 1935, without regard to civil service laws under specific emergency acts, to acquire competitive classified civil service status. This is contingent upon recommendations by the Comptroller General and meeting certain conditions like continuous satisfactory service, qualifying in noncompetitive tests, US citizenship, and not being disqualified by civil service rules or laws. The order also stipulates that all positions affected by it will be classified civil service positions, and vacancies will be filled according to competitive civil service requirements. The document does not directly address ideological tilts, immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion in a significant way. The order seems to be primarily focused on regularizing the civil service status of existing employees within the GAO, with some emphasis on ensuring qualifications and adherence to civil service rules. Therefore, most axes should be scored as neutral.
